subject: Why I like QS

messageBody:
I got interrupted before by my son coming home from school and
accidentally hit send rather than save. I alas often make the opposite
mistake too...

Anyway some may wonder why I favor QS when I do believe a reformed
Latin alphabet is possible. There are two answers.

The first is that like Shaw I don't think a reformed Latin alphabet is
*politically* possible, because people will for various reasons
disparage an orthography with diacritics, new letters, new digraphs or
even just new spellings using the old letters and digraphs.

The second reason is that QS is also a script reform. The Latin
alphabet, with whatever orthography, is slow going and wasteful of
both time and muscular effort and usually paper and ink too. For real
speed and saving of muscular effort not even QS can beat real
shorthand, where signs are reduced to really minimal graphic shapes.
However shorthand has some disadvantages which QS overcomes:

Shorthand is usually not space saving, since it exploits differences
in both horizontal and vertical line-length, and often three degrees
of both length and height, not just two degrees of height as Latin
Alphabet or QS. This in turn causes the so-called climbing effects,
with word-shapes crawling upward and downward. QS by contrast 'stays
between the lines'.

The differences between shorthand sign shapes are so minimalized that
shorthand lacks redundancy, making it hard to read, even to the reader
after some time.

To gain speed and minimize crawling effects shorthands make extensive
use of alternate shapes, cluster signs and 'advanced' abbreviations,
which take effort to learn and to remember to deploy when writing.
Those of Senior QS are a breeze by comparison.

In addition most English shorthand systems take liberties with vowels,
writing them effectively or not at all. This however is not a
necessary trait in a shorthand, as shown by Melin's Swedish Shorthand,
and my adaptation of it to English, which I ought to write a
description of some time.

/BP

--
/ BP
